context: During the late 19th Century the Jadidists established themselves as <a0_0><b4_0>an Islamic social movement<b4_0/> throughout the region<a0_0/>. Although <b8_0>the Jadidists<b8_0/> were pro-modernization and not necessarily anti-Russian the <a1_0>Russians<a1_0/> viewed the movement as a threat.[citation needed] Russian troops were required to restore order during uprisings against the Khanate of Kokand <a2_0>between <b5_0>1910 and 1913<b5_0/><a2_0/>. Further violence occurred in July 1916 when demonstrators attacked Russian soldiers in Khujand over <a3_0><b6_0>the threat of forced conscription during World War I<b6_0/><a3_0/>. Despite <b7_0>Russian<b7_0/> troops quickly bringing Khujand back under control, clashes continued throughout the year in various locations in Tajikistan.[citation needed]
